data.text: INDEX
Appendix 1: Guide to IV drug preparation and administration Appendix 2: Conversion of units
Appendix 3: Online drug calculator and prescription chart Appendix 4: Salbutamol calculation dosing chart
Appendix 5: Preliminary Equality Analysis
Purpose

This guideline aims to provide health care professionals with practical information for the safe preparation and administration of drug infusions which may be given to seriously ill children and young people.
Staff Training
All medical and nursing staff are to ensure that their knowledge, competencies and skills are up-to-date.
All registered nurses will be trained in the preparation and administration of infusions before undertaking any drug infusion.
Junior medical staff will be trained during their induction process.
IV Drug Preparation and Administration
The Guide to IV drug preparation and administration is set out in Appendix
In the monographs in Appendix 1 weight refers to the child's weight in kilograms.

The monographs in Appendix 1 have been compiled as an additional resource to the on-line calculator outlined in Appendix  For ease of manual calculation there may be some differences between the monographs and the on-line calculator. Please follow either one or the other, do not use both in order to avoid confusion and mistakes.
Conversion of Units is set out in Appendix
On-line drug calculator is set out in Appendix
Infection Prevention
All staff should follow Trust guidelines on infection prevention ensuring that they effectively ‘decontaminate their hands' before and after each procedure.
All staff should ensure that they follow Trust guidelines on infection prevention using Aseptic Non-Touch Technique (ANTT) when carrying out procedures.
Audit and Monitoring
Non-compliance with the guideline is monitored as part of the datix reporting system. Serious incidents will be reported and monitored through the Children's
Urgent and Emergency Group.
Annual audit of infusions used for critically ill children.
Communication
Approved guidelines are published monthly in the Trust's Focus which is sent via email to staff.
Approved guidelines will be disseminated to appropriate staff via email after ratification of this guideline.
References:
Paediatric Emergency Guidelines CATS website www.cats.nhs.uk
BNFC online accessed June 2019 Available at: https://bnfc.nice.org.uk/
UCLH Injectable Medicines Administration Guide, 2010. 3rd ed. London: Wiley- Blackwell.
Available to loan via the Warner Library

Preparing And Administering Intravenous Infusions Of Drugs For Children And Young People/ 09065 / 4.0
APPENDIX 1:  Guide to IV drug preparation and administration
Adrenaline (Epinephrine)
Preparation: Adrenaline (Epinephrine) 1 in 1000 (1mg/ml) 1ml or 5ml amps

table_items.text: All children (usually via central line but may be given peripherally)
For 0.3 mg / Kg in 50ml standard infusion 1ml / hour = 0.1 mcg / kg / min 5ml / hour = 0.5 mcg / kg / min

data.text: Common Y site compatibilities; Dopamine; Dobutamine; Morphine; Midazolam; Noradrenaline (in glucose 5%) Incompatibilities: Aminophylline; Sodium bicarbonate and other alkaline solutions; Thiopental
Aminophylline
Preparation: Aminophylline 250mg in 10ml amps

table_items.text: 500mg in 500ml standard infusion 1ml / kg / hr = 1mg / kg / hr 0.5ml / kg / hr = 0.5 mg / kg / hr
All children 5 mg / kg total dose (maximum 500mg) given over 20 minutes. Omit in those receiving maintenance oral theophylline.
Child 1 month – 11 years 1 mg / kg / hour Child 12 – 18 years 0.5 – 0.7 mg / kg / hour

data.text: The loading dose should be given over 20 minutes with ECG monitoring.
Monitor serum theophylline levels in patients already receiving oral treatment and in those receiving prolonged treatment (>24 hours)
Common Y site compatibilities: Morphine; Potassium Chloride 40mmol/litre
Incompatibilities: Midazolam; Salbutamol
Dobutamine
Preparation: Dobutamine 250mg in 20ml amps

table_items.text: For children <15 Kg via central line
For 15mg/Kg in 50ml standard infusion 1ml / hour = 5mcg/kg/min 4ml / hour = 20mcg/kg/min

data.text: Dobutamine should usually be given by central line. If it is essential to give it peripherally discuss with Consultant and use a maximum concentration of 5mg/ml or less (250mg in 50ml). If necessary stronger concentrations can be given via a central line.
Common Y site compatibilities: Adrenaline, Noradrenaline, Dopamine, Morphine, Midazolam, Fentanyl, Insulin, Potassium chloride, Vasopressin, Vecuronium
Incompatibilities: Furosemide, Sodium bicarbonate
Dopamine
Preparation: Dopamine 200mg in 5ml amps

table_items.text: For 15mg/Kg in 50ml standard infusion 1ml / hr = 5mcg/kg/min 4ml / hr = 20mcg/kg/min

data.text: Dopamine should usually be given by central line. If it is essential to give it peripherally discuss with Consultant and use a maximum concentration of 80mg in 50ml.
Common Y site compatibilities: Adrenaline, Noradrenaline, Dopamine, Morphine, Midazolam, Fentanyl, Potassium chloride, Vasopressin, Vecuronium
Incompatibilities: Sodium bicarbonate, Furosemide
Magnesium Sulphate
Preparation: Magnesium sulphate 10% (100mg/ml) amps  Magnesium 10% injection contains 100mg/ml of magnesium

table_items.text: 40 mg / kg i.e. 0.4ml / kg of 10% injection (maximum 2G) Give by slow intravenous injection over 20 minutes (maximum rate 10mg/kg/minute).
Use 10% (100mg/ml) injection and give neat via central or peripheral line.
2g by slow intravenous injection over 20 minutes

data.text: Preparation: Magnesium sulphate 50% (500mg/ml) amps: Magnesium sulfate 50% must ALWAYS be diluted before use. Magnesium 50% injection contains 500mg/ml magnesium
A concentration of up to 10% magnesium sulfate (100mg/mL; 0.4mmol/mL magnesium) is recommended for IV administration in children.(5)

To prepare a 5% solution (50mg/mL) solution dilute each 1mL of magnesium sulfate 50% with 9mL of diluent. To prepare a 10% solution (100mg/mL) solution dilute each 1mL of magnesium sulfate 50% with 4mL of diluent.
Dilute with sodium chloride 0.9% or glucose 5%. Mix thoroughly, inverting the syringe or bag at least 5 times to avoid 'layering'.
Can be run through the same line as morphine sulphate
Midazolam
Preparation: Midazolam 10mg in 2ml amps; 5mg in 5ml amps

table_items.text: A slow bolus of 150-200 mcg/ kg may be required as a loading dose 0.83ml = 100mcg/kg
1 – 5 mcg / kg / min (equivalent to 60 – 300 mcg / kg / hour).
A slow bolus of 150-200 mcg / kg may be required as a loading dose 0.1ml/kg = 100mcg/kg
1 – 5 mcg / kg / min (equivalent to 60 – 300 mcg / kg / hour).

data.text: Common Y site compatibilities: Dopamine & Dobutamine (if all in Glucose 5%), Fentanyl, Morphine, Noradrenaline and adrenaline (if all in Glucose 5%)
Morphine
Ampoules available in a variety of strengths e.g. 10mg/ml, 30mg/ml

table_items.text: For a 1mg/Kg in 50 ml standard infusion 0.5ml / hr = 10mcg/kg/hr 2ml / hr = 40mcg/kg/hr

data.text: Common Y site compatibilities: Adrenaline; Noradrenaline; Dopamine; Dobutamine; Midazolam
Noradrenaline
Preparation: Noradrenaline 1 in 1000 4ml amps (1mg/ml noradrenaline base)

table_items.text: Glucose 5% or 10% (Can be made up in 0.9% sodium chloride but watch for discolouration. If this occurs discard syringe)
For a 0.3mg/Kg in 50ml standard infusion 1ml / hour = 0.1 mcg / kg / min 5ml / hour = 0.5 mcg / kg / min

data.text: Common Y site compatibilities: Adrenaline; Dopamine; Dobutamine; Morphine; Midazolam; Vasopressin
Salbutamol * (see administration chart for calculated doses appendix 4)
Preparation: Salbutamol 5mg in 5ml amps; 500mcg in 1ml amps

table_items.text: All children via peripheral line or central line
For a 25mg in 50ml standard infusion (500mcg/ml solution) 0.12ml / Kg / hour = 1 mcg / Kg / minute
1 month – 1 year: 5 mcg / kg total dose given over 5 minutes. 2-17 years: 15 mcg / kg total dose given over 5 minutes. Max dose = 250mcg Dilute to 50mcg/ml solution before administration
1 – 2 mcg / kg / minute = 60 – 120 mcg / kg / hr Doses above 2 mcg / kg / min should only be used on recommendation of a consultant paediatrician after liaison with the CATS team
All children via central line only
For a 1mg in 1ml standard infusion 0.06ml / Kg / hour = 1 mcg / Kg / minute

data.text: Common Y site compatibilities: Potassium
Incompatibilities: Aminophylline
Vecuronium
Preparation: Vecuronium 10mg amps (reconstitute to 10mg in 5ml with water for injection provided)

table_items.text: Reconstitute each 10mg vial with 5ml water for injections
1 – 4 mcg / kg / min (equivalent to 60 – 240 mcg / kg / hour).
Reconstitute each 10mg vial with 5ml water for injections
1 – 4 mcg / kg / min (equivalent to 60 – 240 mcg / kg / hour).

data.text: Common Y site compatibilities: Adrenaline; Noradrenaline (in glucose only); Dopamine; Dobutamine; Morphine; Midazolam; Fentanyl (in glucose only)
Incompatibilities: Furosemide
3% Hypertonic Saline (or commercially ready made 2.7% saline when available)
Indication for use: Treatment of cerebral oedema and raised intracranial pressure (e.g. head injury, DKA)

table_items.text: Preparation of solution for IV administration if ready made solution not available
All children (preferably via central line but may be given peripherally)
Remove 36ml from 500ml bag of 0.9% normal saline Add 36ml 30% saline to 500ml bag of 0.9% normal saline = 500ml bag of 3% Hypertonic Saline
3 - 5ml / kg *Take the prescribed volume out of the bag and administer to the patient separately

data.text: Preparing And Administering Intravenous Infusions Of Drugs For Children And Young People/ 09065 / 4.0
Appendix 2: Conversion of Units
Units commonly used are: microgram, milligram, gram & kilogram There are:
1000 micrograms in 1 milligram
1000 milligrams in 1gram
1000 grams in 1kilogram
However, there are others which may be used:
Good Practice Guidelines:
Micrograms should always be written in full (may see mcg or μg)
Nanograms should always be written in full (may see ng or ηg)
Decimal places should be avoided i.e. 0.5g should be written as 500mg.
To convert from smaller units to larger ones, we need to divide by 1000,
Or to convert from a larger unit to a smaller unit, we need to multiply by
Appendix 3: Online electronic drug calculator and prescription chart
Online drug calculators can be used to assist in calculating doses of medicines needed in an emergency situation.
CATS paediatric retrieval service:  www.cats.nhs.uk
